text: Does anyone know about a reliable source of weather forecasts for e.g. 7 days from today? Pretty much all somewhat mainstream applications for that sort of thing are.. hard to like, I much prefer output in the form of graphs and such (like e.g. from `curl <http://v2.wttr.in|v2.wttr.in>`, only that is limited to 2 days from now)

elements.text: Does anyone know about a reliable source of weather forecasts for e.g. 7 days from today? Pretty much all somewhat mainstream applications for that sort of thing are.. hard to like, I much prefer output in the form of graphs and such (like e.g. from
curl
v2.wttr.in
, only that is limited to 2 days from now)

text: <http://yr.no|yr.no> is well respected in Europe. They have nice graphs like <https://www.yr.no/en/forecast/graph/2-2643743/United%20Kingdom/England/Greater%20London/London|https://www.yr.no/en/forecast/graph/2-2643743/United%20Kingdom/England/Greater%20London/London>

attachments.title: Weather forecast for London
attachments.text: Todays weather forecast, by the hour and long term. See the forecast as a table or graph.

text: Windy is my favorite weather source: <https://www.windy.com/|https://www.windy.com/>

elements.text: Windy is my favorite weather source:
https://www.windy.com/

text: Has multiple sources, tons of data, great visualizations

text: thank you, the visualizations are nice!

text: Windy makes me want to drop everything and learn about meteorology

the app by the german weather service is decent but I don't know if it covers the entire world.

text: <https://darksky.net/|https://darksky.net/> is nice but they removed their Android version after selling out to Apple

attachments.title: Weather
attachments.text: Dark Sky is the most accurate source of hyperlocal weather information: with down-to-the-minute forecasts for your exact location, you'll never get caught in the rain again. (It's like magic!)

elements.text: https://darksky.net/
is nice but they removed their Android version after selling out to Apple
